question: European regulations (CS Ops-1) state that the maximum permissible deviations after compensation are:

choices.choice: one degree for a remote indicating compass, and ten degrees for a direct reading magnetic compass.
three degrees for a direct reading magnetic compass, and one degree for a remote indicating compass.
ten degrees for a remote indicating compass, and one degree for a direct reading magnetic compass.
one degree for a direct reading magnetic compass, and eleven degrees for a slaved compass.

explanation:
In accordance with CS OPS-1 (European Regulations) the aircraft’s compasses must, after correction, be within the following limits:

Direct Reading Magnetic Compass +/- 10°
Remote Indicating Compass +/- 1°
subject: Instruments

question: Compass swings should be carried out:

choices.choice: on the apron.
only on the compass swinging base or site.
at the holding point.
on the active runway.

explanation:
The basic method of determining deviation is to compare the aircraft’s heading compass reading with magnetic heading as defined by a high quality ‘land or datum’ compass. This comparison of aircraft compass and magnetic datum readings is carried out in an area selected specifically for this purpose.

Therefore, the aims of a compass swing are as follows:

  • To observe / determine the deviations / differences between magnetic north (observed on a landing compass) and compass north (observed in the aircraft) on a series of headings.
  • To correct / remove as much deviation as possible.
  • To record the residual deviation which is left after the compass has been adjusted.

The magnetic deviation observed during a compass swing can be said to be derived from hard iron and soft iron magnetism and this total field can in turn, for our purposes, be later resolved into two further combined components (coefficients B and C).
subject: Instruments

question: Aircraft magnetism caused by Vertical Soft Iron:

choices.choice: varies with magnetic heading but not with magnetic latitude
varies with magnetic latitude but not with heading.
it is not affected magnetic latitude or heading.
varies as the cosine of the compass heading.

explanation:
Aircraft Magnetism and Vertical Soft Iron (VSI) Magnetism

Aircraft magnetism caused by vertical soft iron (VSI) varies with magnetic latitude but not with the magnetic heading.

Soft iron magnetism is induced in parts of the aircraft structure by surrounding fields, the most important of these being the Earth. The Earth’s magnetic field has both a vertical (Z) and horizontal (H) component.

For the purpose of this explanation, we consider only vertical soft iron (VSI) magnetism, where Z represents the vertical component of the Earth’s magnetic field and H represents the horizontal component.

  • The component Z has an increasing effect with latitude, as the compass magnets try to align with the Earth’s flux lines.
  • Consequently, VSI magnetism varies with latitude.
  • At the equator, Z = 0 (as there is no vertical component), and the horizontal component H is at its maximum, meaning no VSI magnetism is induced.
subject: Instruments

question: Deviation due to coefficient A is mainly caused by:

choices.choice: hard iron force acting along the longitudinal axis.
hard and soft iron forces acting along the lateral axis.
vertical soft iron forces.
a misaligned lubber line.

explanation:
Correction of Coefficients

The principle for correcting coefficients is the same for any system and can be summed up as follows:

  • Coefficient A:
    • A mechanical problem of a displaced lubber line.
    • Corrected by loosening the bolts holding the compass body or, in the case of the RIMC, the detector unit, and carefully turning it until the correct heading is in place.
  • Coefficient B:
    • Correction required because of magnetic deviating forces acting upon the DRMC or the detector unit, causing errors known as deviation.
    • First, calculate the error to be removed, or more correctly, the heading you wish to make the compass read.
    • This correction is performed on an easterly or westerly heading.
  • Coefficient C:
    • Correction required because of magnetic deviating forces acting upon the DRMC or the detector unit, causing errors known as deviation.
    • First, calculate the error to be removed, or more correctly, the heading you wish to make the compass read.
    • This correction is performed on a northerly or southerly heading.
subject: Instruments
